title: Tripping Operations in Tight Windows
description: Tripping in HPHT and tight-window wells requires precise management of swab and surge pressures. A swab kick or surge-induced loss can quickly escalate in environments with limited kick tolerance. This module covers safe tripping practices.
objectives: Execute connection flow checks and trip monitoring
Implement trip margins and pump-out-of-hole procedures
Respond to tripping-induced well control events

keyTopics.content: Pipe movement displaces fluid, creating pressure changes. Pulling up (swab) reduces BHP - risk of kick. Running in (surge) increases BHP - risk of losses. Effect increases with speed, pipe OD, hole size, and mud rheology.

Trip margin is extra MW added to compensate for swab effect. Typical 0.2-0.5 ppg depending on well conditions. On Phoenix-702, 0.3 ppg trip margin is specified - but actual swab depends on trip speed and rheology.

Before and after each connection, verify well is static. Typical: 5 minutes, <0.5 bbl acceptable. On HPHT wells with limited kick tolerance, flow checks may be more stringent. Don't assume - verify every connection.
Maintaining circulation while tripping eliminates swab effect and maintains ECD. Takes longer but prevents swab kicks. In tight-window HPHT wells, the extra time is worth the reduced risk.
Real-time PWD shows actual BHP during trips. Compare to pore pressure - if BHP approaches PP, slow down or pump. Don't rely on calculated swab - measure it. PWD is essential in tight windows.
Tight spots, reactive shales, differential sticking zones. Plan trip speed for each section. Note problem depths on the trip sheet. Extra vigilance when pulling through known problem areas.

referenceWellContext.concerns: 8 bbl kick tolerance at TD - no room for swab kicks

operationalPrinciples: Speed kills in tight windows - slow and controlled
Flow check every connection in critical sections
Pump out of hole when margins are thin
Know your problem zones before you start
